Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Warehouse Integration in Enterprise-Wide Supply Chain Planning under Uncertainty

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) collaborative research award is to develop a set of innovative models and solutions for analyzing the three-way interaction among warehousing, inventory, and transportation decisions. The warehouse-inventory-transportation problem (WITP) for multi-echelon and multi-period supply chains is proposed and modeled through a stochastic integer quadratically-constrained program (SIQCP). Decisions associated with products with differing life-cycles flowing through the supply chain are also considered in the WITP. To solve industry-sized stochastic WITP instances, a seamless integration of decomposition approaches for stochastic integer linear programming (SILP) and continuous convex relaxation techniques for deterministic integer quadratically-constrained programming (IQCP) will be pursued.

If successful, this research will develop novel insights into interactions between the three key supply chain drivers and will prescribe low cost, realistic, plans to supply chain managers. This research will facilitate innovation and excellence in decision analytics at over 600,000 warehouses with annual expenditures of over $100 billion, leading to substantial economic benefit to enterprises both nationally and globally. After successful validation in collaboration with our industry co-PI, opportunities for potential commercialization within the $6.1 billion annual worldwide supply chain software market will be considered. Key findings from this research will be incorporated in an interactive educational website to demonstrate the interplay among warehousing, inventory, and transportation decisions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) collaborative research award, PI Kong and his research group have developed a set of solution methods for analyzing the three-way interaction among warehousing, inventory, and transportation decisions. The analysis is based on the formulated warehouse-inventory-transportation problem (WITP) for multi-echelon and multi-period supply chains. In such a problem, we make tactic decisions on warehouse technology selection and operational decisions on warehouse workforce deployment.

This research was motivated by the current practice of distribution planning, specifically at our industry partner, a US-based apparel supply chain. This supply chain sells to consumers through retail and e-commerce channels. Their warehouse, the only one in the supply chain, manages the flow of 6500 -- 8000 products supplied by over 100 domestic and overseas vendors, and replenishes over 300 retail stores situated in nearly 40 states across the nation. Although this warehouse serves as a hub in the supply chain, it operates in a reactive mode; that is, inventory and transportation plans are determined first and warehouse plan is determined later. This sequential approach results in the warehouse experiencing substantial variation in daily workload, which causes the warehouse manager to scramble for resources during peak times and suffer from resource under-utilization during drought time. Furthermore, the product demand is clearly uncertain with cyclic peak and slow times over long periods of time. Finally, decisions in the WITP are associated with products with differing life-cycles flowing through the supply chain.

In this research, Kong mainly took charge of stochastic programming solution approach. Our solution development harnesses the power of commercially available stochastic programming modeling tool and scenario decomposition based stochastic programming solver in the PySP software package. It also achieves seamless integration of various approximation schemes to successfully reduce the computational challenge. The numerical studies on industry sized instances suggest satisfactory performance.

This research has helped developed novel insights into interactions between the three key supply chain drivers and will prescribe low cost, realistic, plans to supply chain managers. This research has faciliated innovation and excellence in decision analytics at over 600,000 warehouses with annual expenditures of over $100 billionm, leading to substantial economic benefit to enterprise both nationally and globally. With successful collaboration with our industry co-PI, opportunities for potential commercialization within the $6.1 billion annual worldwide supply chain software market have been considered. Key findings from this research have been incorporated in an interactive educational website to demostrate the interplay among warehousing, inventory, and transportation decisions.

Through this awarded project, Kong has created opportunties for training and professional development. Kong has graduated a master's student within 3 publications and several conference presentations. Kong has strengthened his collaboration with Dr. Parikh, his main collabroator on various research topics. During this project, our collaboration led to their second joint NSF CMMI award. Furthermore, Kong has established collaborations in China to deal with distribution center planning and operations management with the objective of coordinating various supply chain entities. For example, Kong has collaborated with Chinese scholars on integrated scheduling of granulation, packaging, and routing operations in fresh agri-food online retailing. Meanwhile, Kong has established close collaboration with process systems engineering researchers at Purdue Chemical Engineering.
